defaultData.name: Manu Nunu - Rock Pigeon
defaultData.description: Originally from Europe and North Africa. Gray-blue with iridescent neck feathers. Often seen in flocks on sidewalks and rooftops.

defaultData.name: Zebra Dove
defaultData.description: Native to Southeast Asia. Small and gray with zebra-like stripes. Commonly seen walking on lawns and cooing softly.

defaultData.name: Manu ʻEleʻele - Common Myna
defaultData.description: Introduced from India. Brown with a yellow eye patch and black head. Loud and social, often walking in pairs or groups.

defaultData.name: Warbling White-eye
defaultData.description: Native to East Asia. Small green bird with a white eye ring. Active forager in trees, feeding on nectar and insects.

defaultData.name: Red-crested Cardinal
defaultData.description: Native to South America. Gray body with a vivid red head. Seen foraging on the ground and perched on fences.

defaultData.name: Kōlea - Pacific Golden-Plover
defaultData.description: Migrates from Alaska. Brown and gold speckled with a short bill. Seen alone on grassy lawns during fall and winter.

defaultData.name: House Sparrow
defaultData.description: Introduced from Europe. Small brown bird with streaky back. Common around buildings and eateries, often in flocks.

defaultData.name: Ehako - Spotted Dove
defaultData.description: Native to Asia. Larger dove with a spotted collar and gray-brown plumage. Frequently heard cooing in trees or on wires.

defaultData.name: Common Waxbill
defaultData.description: Native to sub-Saharan Africa. Tiny finch with gray body, red eye stripe, and red beak. Moves in flocks through tall grass.

defaultData.name: White-rumped Shama
defaultData.description: Introduced from Asia. Glossy black with white rump and long tail. Known for its melodious song, prefers forested areas.

defaultData.name: ʻApapane
defaultData.description: Native to Hawaiʻi. Bright red with black wings and tail. Found in native forests, especially near ʻōhiʻa blossoms.

defaultData.name: Red-vented Bulbul
defaultData.description: Introduced from India. Brownish bird with a black crest and red vent. Active in gardens and urban forests.

defaultData.name: Rose-ringed Parakeet
defaultData.description: Native to Africa and South Asia. Bright green with a long tail and rose-colored neck ring. Seen in noisy flocks near tall trees.

defaultData.name: Chestnut Munia
defaultData.description: Native to Southeast Asia. Chestnut body with black head and stubby beak. Forages in flocks in grassy areas.

defaultData.name: Manu o Kū - White Tern
defaultData.description: Native seabird. Pure white with large black eyes and slender wings. Lays eggs on bare tree branches in urban Honolulu.

defaultData.name: Java Sparrow
defaultData.description: Native to Java and Bali. Plump with gray body, white cheeks, and pink beak. Seen in flocks feeding on grass seeds.

defaultData.name: Western Cattle Egret
defaultData.description: Native to Africa and Asia. White body, yellow bill and legs. Seen in fields, often near cattle or lawn mowers.

defaultData.name: Saffron Finch
defaultData.description: Native to South America. Bright yellow with orange on the head. Forages in open grassy areas, often in pairs.

defaultData.name: Moa - Chicken
defaultData.description: Domesticated and feral worldwide. Varied in color with red comb. Roams freely, scratching the ground with chicks nearby.

defaultData.name: Yellow-fronted Canary
defaultData.description: Native to Africa. Yellow body with greenish wings and streaks. Sings brightly from shrubs and open areas.

defaultData.name: Northern Cardinal
defaultData.description: Introduced from North America. Males are red, females brown with red highlights. Sings whistled phrases from trees.

defaultData.name: Red-whiskered Bulbul
defaultData.description: Native to Asia. Black crest, white cheeks, and red patch behind the eye. Found in shrubby areas, calling in pairs.

defaultData.name: Koloa Maoli - Hawaiian Duck
defaultData.description: Endemic to Hawaiʻi. Brown mottled duck similar in appearance to female mallards. Often found in streams, wetlands, and taro patches; shy and quiet.

defaultData.name: Mallard
defaultData.description: Introduced from North America. Males have a green head and yellow bill; females are brown with orange bills. Common in ponds and sometimes hybridize with Hawaiian ducks.

defaultData.name: Aeʻo - Black-necked Stilt
defaultData.description: Endemic subspecies in Hawaiʻi. Tall, slender wader with long pink legs, black upperparts, and white underparts. Found in shallow wetlands, often seen foraging in groups.

defaultSightings.name: Manu Nunu - Rock Pigeon
defaultSightings.description: Originally from Europe and North Africa. Gray-blue with iridescent neck feathers. Often seen in flocks on sidewalks and rooftops.
